explanations.A: Not quite. Your second fraction hasn't changed. What happens when the division becomes a multiplication?
explanations.B: It looks like you have worked out the answer if the second fraction had been 1/5. What changes when it is 2/5?
explanations.C: Comparing left to right, the division is now a multiplication and the first fraction has stayed the same. This means we have to change the second fraction to its reciprocal (we flip the fraction). So 2/5 becomes 5/2.
explanations.D: It looks like you have found the reciprocal (flipped version) of the wrong fraction.

explanations.A: Comparing left to right, the division is now a multiplication and the first fraction has stayed the same. This means we have to change the second fraction to its reciprocal (we flip the fraction). So 3/4 becomes 4/3.
explanations.B: It looks like you have found the reciprocal (flipped version) of the wrong fraction.
explanations.C: Not quite. Your second fraction hasn't changed. What happens when the division becomes a multiplication?
explanations.D: It looks like you have worked out the answer if the second fraction had been 1/4. What changes when it is 3/4?

explanations.A: If we cut a pizza into 8 slices then each slice is 1/8 of the pizza. If Beth eats 7 of the slices there is only 1 slice left. Does this calculation give 1/8?
explanations.B: Is it possible to cut a pizza into 7 slices and then eat 8 slices?
explanations.C: Is it possible to cut a pizza into 7 slices and then eat 8 slices?
explanations.D: If we cut a pizza into 8 slices then each slice is 1/8 of the pizza. If Beth eats 7 of the slices then she has had 7 lots of 1/8 which is 7 âœ• 1/8

explanations.A: If we cut a cake into 6 slices then each slice is 1/6 of the cake. If Ivan eats 5 of the slices then he has had 5 lots of 1/6 which is 5 âœ• 1/6
explanations.B: Is it possible to cut a cake into 5 slices and then eat 6 slices?
explanations.C: Is it possible to cut a cake into 5 slices and then eat 6 slices?
explanations.D: If we cut a cake into 6 slices then each slice is 1/6 of the cake. If Ivan eats 5 of the slices there is only 1 slice left. Does this calculation give 1/6?

explanations.B: It looks like you have multiplied 5/8 and 1/6. We need to solve 5/8 âœ• ? = 1/6

explanations.A: Product means 'âœ•'. We need to solve 3/7 âœ• ? = 2/5
explanations.B: Product means 'âœ•'. We need to solve 3/7 âœ• ? = 2/5 and that means that ? = 2/5 Ã· 3/7 = 2/5 âœ• 7/3 = 14/15

explanations.A: Not quite. How do we get from 4/9 to 4? What do we multiply by? We then multiply the area by that same number.
explanations.B: We know that 4/9ths of a litre covers 1 square metre. We are interested in how much 4 litres cover. To get from 4/9 to 4 we multiply by 9. So we do the same thing to the area. 1 âœ• 9 = 9.
explanations.C: Not quite. How do we get from 4/9 to 4? What do we multiply by? We then multiply the area by that same number.
explanations.D: Not quite. How do we get from 4/9 to 4? What do we multiply by? We then multiply the area by that same number.

explanations.A: Not quite. How do we get from 3/7 to 6? What do we multiply by to get a whole number? What can we then multiply by to get 6? We then multiply the area by those same numbers.
explanations.B: We know that 3/7ths of a litre covers 1 square metre. We are interested in how much 6 litres cover. To get from 3/7 to 3 we multiply by 7. Then to get from 3 to 6 we multiply by 2. So we do the same thing to the area. 1 âœ• 7 âœ• 2 = 14.
explanations.C: Not quite. How do we get from 3/7 to 6? What do we multiply by to get a whole number? What can we then multiply by to get 6? We then multiply the area by those same numbers.
explanations.D: Not quite. How do we get from 3/7 to 6? What do we multiply by to get a whole number? What can we then multiply by to get 6? We then multiply the area by those same numbers.
